article_title: Time to stop pointing fingers on health care and do something
article_text:
Time to stop pointing fingers on health care and do something

During a crisis, we expect our political leaders to respond. We expect them to, well, lead.

article_metadata.description: The fact that 88,000 people in Houston have lost their health insurance plans, including thousands in active cancer treatment, is a crisis in my book.  "[...] we're only arguing about which provider they can go see, not 'can they be covered at all,' " says Ken Janda, CEO of the nonprofit health plan Community Health Choice.  Recall former Gov. Rick Perry's ominous suggestion that marketplace navigators, people trained to help others sign up for insurance, were scammers just out for your Social Security number!  "The missing ingredient that's absolutely necessary is state-run education and outreach efforts," said state Rep. Chris Turner, D-Arlington.  The state under this leadership has been not just unwilling to help but actively working to undermine the opportunity for more Texans to get insurance coverage.  A conservative state like Arkansas agreed to expand Medicaid, and then used creative strategies to funnel its young and healthy population into the insurance exchange, while Texas refused to expand Medicaid at all.  State Rep. Garnet Coleman, D-Houston, a longtime health care guru, went further: "If we had those young adults in the exchange, the plans would be making money, and they wouldn't have to drop the PPOs."  Lawmakers could require insurers to offer PPOs, he said, and they could give the Texas Department of Insurance the power to crack down on companies that are increasingly narrowing networks - limiting access to doctors, hospitals and services - to save money.  [...] it's little comfort to cancer patients in the middle of a health care crisis.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lisa Falkenberg
